content: How can I help you today?

I've been struggling to sleep lately. My mind just races every night, mostly about work and the worry of getting fired. It's been overwhelming, and I don't really know what to do. My partner thought seeing you might help.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like the thoughts about work and the fear of losing your job have been weighing heavily on you, especially when you're trying to rest. That feeling of being overwhelmed can make it tough to get the sleep you need. What do you think has been the hardest part of this experience for you?

I think the hardest part is feeling like there’s nothing I can do to fix it. Work is so uncertain, and I’m just constantly worrying about how I’ll take care of my family if something happens. The pressure is always there, and I guess it’s turned my brain into overdrive at night. It’s exhausting.

That pressure must feel relentless, especially when it involves your responsibility toward your family. It's natural to worry about their well-being when work feels uncertain, and it's understandable how that could keep your mind in overdrive. Even though it feels like there's nothing you can do to fix it, you're here and open to talking about it, which shows a lot of strength. What do you think might bring even a small sense of relief right now?

Honestly, I don’t even know what would help at this point. Maybe just feeling like I have some sort of control over the situation? It’s hard because I can’t control what happens at work, and that’s where all the stress is coming from. I guess I wish I could just shut my brain off, even if it’s only when I need to sleep, you know?

Wanting a sense of control makes a lot of sense, especially when the stress is coming from something you can't directly change, like work uncertainty. And it sounds like being able to quiet your mind and rest would mean a lot to you right now—like it could be one small area where things feel more manageable. What do you think has made it hard to feel that sense of control lately?

I think it’s because everything at work feels so unpredictable. I can’t plan for what’s coming, and that uncertainty is just eating away at me. I feel like I’m bracing myself for the worst, but it’s exhausting, and I don’t know how to relax or let go of it. It’s hard to focus on anything else when it feels like everything could fall apart.

That unpredictable feeling must be incredibly draining, especially when it’s consuming so much of your energy and focus. Bracing for the worst all the time can really take a toll, particularly when it feels like there's no clear path forward. Even though it’s hard to relax right now, it sounds like part of you is yearning for a way to release some of that tension. What would it mean to you if you could find small moments of peace, even just for a little while?

It would mean a lot, honestly. Even just a few moments to feel like I'm not drowning in all this stress would be a huge relief. I want to be able to enjoy time with my family without constantly worrying or letting these thoughts take over. But it just feels impossible sometimes.

It’s really clear how deeply you care about being present for your family, even while carrying this stress. Wanting those moments of peace shows how much you value your time with them and how committed you are to finding relief, despite how impossible it feels right now. What kind of connection or activities with your family have felt meaningful to you lately, even during this tough time?

Spending time with my kids always feels meaningful, but even that’s been harder with everything on my mind. Usually, simple things like playing with them or reading bedtime stories help me feel grounded, but lately, it feels like my head isn’t fully there. I want to be more present, but it’s like the stress keeps pulling me away, and that’s one of the hardest parts of all this.

It’s clear how much your family means to you, and even when the stress is pulling you away, your desire to truly connect with them speaks volumes about what matters most to you. It sounds like those activities—playing with your kids or reading bedtime stories—are really special moments that help you feel grounded when your mind isn’t racing. If you were able to feel more present in those moments, even just little by little, what difference do you think that could make for you and your family?
It’s okay to take your time. Whenever you’re ready, feel free to share your thoughts or feelings—this space is here for you.
It’s okay if you need a moment to process that question. Take your time, and when you’re ready, I’m here to listen and support you.

Thank you for sharing that. It shows how much you care about your process and how you're reflecting deeply on your situation right now. Whenever you're ready, we can keep exploring what matters most to you—no rush at all.

I appreciate that. I think if I could be more present with my family, it would remind me of what I’m working so hard for. It would help me focus on the good things in my life, instead of just the stress and fear of what might happen. It might even make everything feel a little more manageable.

That’s such an important realization—connecting with your family, focusing on the good, and reminding yourself of your motivations could help shift some of the weight of stress and fear. Even the thought of making things feel a little more manageable is a meaningful step forward. What do you think might help you start creating those moments of presence, even if they’re small at first?

That makes a lot of sense. Starting small feels less overwhelming, I guess. Maybe I could set aside even just 10-15 minutes each day to spend fully focused on my kids—no distractions, no work thoughts. It feels like a small step, but maybe it could help me feel a little more connected and grounded. What do you think?

That sounds like a thoughtful and manageable step, and the fact that you’re already thinking about how to make it work shows your commitment to finding balance for yourself and your family. Setting aside a short, focused time each day could be a meaningful way to create those moments of connection that matter so much to you. Would you like to talk more about how you could put this plan into action?
